trans-unit.source: Query data from HDFS-compatible Blob storage | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Query data from HDFS-compatible Blob storage | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: HDInsight uses Blob storage as the big data store for HDFS. Learn how to query data from Blob storage and store results of your analysis.
trans-unit.target: HDInsight uses Blob storage as the big data store for HDFS. Learn how to query data from Blob storage and store results of your analysis.

trans-unit.source: Use HDFS-compatible Azure Blob storage with Hadoop in HDInsight
trans-unit.target: Use HDFS-compatible Azure Blob storage with Hadoop in HDInsight

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, learn how to use low-cost Azure Blob storage with HDInsight, create Azure storage account and Blob storage container, and then address the data inside.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, learn how to use low-cost Azure Blob storage with HDInsight, create Azure storage account and Blob storage container, and then address the data inside.

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob storage is a robust, general-purpose storage solution that integrates seamlessly with HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob storage is a robust, general-purpose storage solution that integrates seamlessly with HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: Through a Hadoop distributed file system (HDFS) interface, the full set of components in HDInsight can operate directly on structured or unstructured data in Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: Through a Hadoop distributed file system (HDFS) interface, the full set of components in HDInsight can operate directly on structured or unstructured data in Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: Storing data in Blob storage enables you to safely delete the HDInsight clusters that are used for computation without losing user data.
trans-unit.target: Storing data in Blob storage enables you to safely delete the HDInsight clusters that are used for computation without losing user data.

trans-unit.source: The asv:// syntax is not supported in HDInsight version 3.0 clusters.
trans-unit.target: The asv:// syntax is not supported in HDInsight version 3.0 clusters.

trans-unit.source: This means that any jobs submitted to an HDInsight version 3.0 cluster that explicitly use the asv:// syntax will fail.
trans-unit.target: This means that any jobs submitted to an HDInsight version 3.0 cluster that explicitly use the asv:// syntax will fail.

trans-unit.source: The wasb:// syntax should be used instead.
trans-unit.target: The wasb:// syntax should be used instead.

trans-unit.source: Also, jobs submitted to any HDInsight version 3.0 clusters that are created with an existing metastore that contains explicit references to resources that use the asv:// syntax will fail.
trans-unit.target: Also, jobs submitted to any HDInsight version 3.0 clusters that are created with an existing metastore that contains explicit references to resources that use the asv:// syntax will fail.

trans-unit.source: These metastores need to be re-created using the wasb:// syntax to address resources.
trans-unit.target: These metastores need to be re-created using the wasb:// syntax to address resources.

trans-unit.source: HDInsight currently only supports block blobs.
trans-unit.target: HDInsight currently only supports block blobs.

trans-unit.source: Most HDFS commands (for example, <html></html>ls<html></html>, <html></html>copyFromLocal<html></html> and <html></html>mkdir<html></html>) still work as expected.
trans-unit.target: Most HDFS commands (for example, <html></html>ls<html></html>, <html></html>copyFromLocal<html></html> and <html></html>mkdir<html></html>) still work as expected.

trans-unit.source: Only the commands that are specific to the native HDFS implementation (which is referred to as DFS), such as <html></html>fschk<html></html> and <html></html>dfsadmin<html></html>, will show different behavior in Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: Only the commands that are specific to the native HDFS implementation (which is referred to as DFS), such as <html></html>fschk<html></html> and <html></html>dfsadmin<html></html>, will show different behavior in Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: For information about provisioning an HDInsight cluster, see <link><linkText>Get Started with HDInsight[hdinsight-get-started]</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>Provision HDInsight clusters[hdinsight-provision]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about provisioning an HDInsight cluster, see <link><linkText>Get Started with HDInsight[hdinsight-get-started]</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>Provision HDInsight clusters[hdinsight-provision]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>HDInsight storage architecture
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>HDInsight storage architecture

trans-unit.source: The following diagram provides an abstract view of the HDInsight storage architecture:
trans-unit.target: The following diagram provides an abstract view of the HDInsight storage architecture:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Hadoop clusters use the HDFS API to access and store structured and unstructured data in Blob storage.</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Hadoop clusters use the HDFS API to access and store structured and unstructured data in Blob storage.</linkText>

trans-unit.source: HDInsight provides access to the distributed file system that is locally attached to the compute nodes.
trans-unit.target: HDInsight provides access to the distributed file system that is locally attached to the compute nodes.

trans-unit.source: This file system can be accessed by using the fully qualified URI, for example:
trans-unit.target: This file system can be accessed by using the fully qualified URI, for example:

trans-unit.source: In addition, HDInsight provides the ability to access data that is stored in Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: In addition, HDInsight provides the ability to access data that is stored in Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: The syntax is:
trans-unit.target: The syntax is:

trans-unit.source: Hadoop supports a notion of the default file system.
trans-unit.target: Hadoop supports a notion of the default file system.

trans-unit.source: The default file system implies a default scheme and authority.
trans-unit.target: The default file system implies a default scheme and authority.

trans-unit.source: It can also be used to resolve relative paths.
trans-unit.target: It can also be used to resolve relative paths.

trans-unit.source: During the HDInsight provisioning process, an Azure Storage account and a specific Azure Blob storage container from that account is designated as the default file system.
trans-unit.target: During the HDInsight provisioning process, an Azure Storage account and a specific Azure Blob storage container from that account is designated as the default file system.

trans-unit.source: In addition to this storage account, you can add additional storage accounts from the same Azure subscription or different Azure subscriptions during the provisioning process.
trans-unit.target: In addition to this storage account, you can add additional storage accounts from the same Azure subscription or different Azure subscriptions during the provisioning process.

trans-unit.source: For instructions about adding additional storage accounts, see <link><linkText>Provision HDInsight clusters[hdinsight-provision]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions about adding additional storage accounts, see <link><linkText>Provision HDInsight clusters[hdinsight-provision]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Containers in the storage accounts that are connected to a cluster: Because the account name and key are associated with the cluster during provisioning, you have full access to the blobs in those containers.
trans-unit.target: Containers in the storage accounts that are connected to a cluster: Because the account name and key are associated with the cluster during provisioning, you have full access to the blobs in those containers.

trans-unit.source: Public containers or public blobs in storage accounts that are NOT connected to a cluster: You have read-only permission to the blobs in the containers.
trans-unit.target: Public containers or public blobs in storage accounts that are NOT connected to a cluster: You have read-only permission to the blobs in the containers.

trans-unit.source: Public containers allow you to get a list of all blobs that are available in that container and get container metadata.
trans-unit.target: Public containers allow you to get a list of all blobs that are available in that container and get container metadata.

trans-unit.source: Public blobs allow you to access the blobs only if you know the exact URL.
trans-unit.target: Public blobs allow you to access the blobs only if you know the exact URL.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <html></html>Restrict access to containers and blobs<html></html>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <html></html>Restrict access to containers and blobs<html></html>.

trans-unit.source: Private containers in storage accounts that are NOT connected to a cluster: You can't access the blobs in the containers unless you define the storage account when you submit the WebHCat jobs.
trans-unit.target: Private containers in storage accounts that are NOT connected to a cluster: You can't access the blobs in the containers unless you define the storage account when you submit the WebHCat jobs.

trans-unit.source: This is explained later in this article.
trans-unit.target: This is explained later in this article.

trans-unit.source: The storage accounts that are defined in the provisioning process and their keys are stored in %HADOOP_HOME%/conf/core-site.xml on the cluster nodes.
trans-unit.target: The storage accounts that are defined in the provisioning process and their keys are stored in %HADOOP_HOME%/conf/core-site.xml on the cluster nodes.

trans-unit.source: The default behavior of HDInsight is to use the storage accounts defined in the core-site.xml file.
trans-unit.target: The default behavior of HDInsight is to use the storage accounts defined in the core-site.xml file.

trans-unit.source: It is not recommended to edit the core-site.xml file because the cluster head node(master) may be reimaged or migrated at any time, and any changes to those files will be lost.
trans-unit.target: It is not recommended to edit the core-site.xml file because the cluster head node(master) may be reimaged or migrated at any time, and any changes to those files will be lost.

trans-unit.source: Multiple WebHCat jobs, including Hive, MapReduce, Hadoop streaming, and Pig, can carry a description of storage accounts and metadata with them.
trans-unit.target: Multiple WebHCat jobs, including Hive, MapReduce, Hadoop streaming, and Pig, can carry a description of storage accounts and metadata with them.

trans-unit.source: (This currently works for Pig with storage accounts, but not for metadata.)
trans-unit.target: (This currently works for Pig with storage accounts, but not for metadata.)

trans-unit.source: In the <link><linkText>Access blobs using Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link> section of this article, there is a sample of this feature.
trans-unit.target: In the <link><linkText>Access blobs using Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link> section of this article, there is a sample of this feature.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Using an HDInsight Cluster with Alternate Storage Accounts and Metastores</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Using an HDInsight Cluster with Alternate Storage Accounts and Metastores</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Blob storage can be used for structured and unstructured data.
trans-unit.target: Blob storage can be used for structured and unstructured data.

trans-unit.source: Blob storage containers store data as key/value pairs, and there is no directory hierarchy.
trans-unit.target: Blob storage containers store data as key/value pairs, and there is no directory hierarchy.

trans-unit.source: However the slash character ( / ) can be used within the key name to make it appear as if a file is stored within a directory structure.
trans-unit.target: However the slash character ( / ) can be used within the key name to make it appear as if a file is stored within a directory structure.

trans-unit.source: For example, a blob's key may be input/log1.txt.
trans-unit.target: For example, a blob's key may be input/log1.txt.

trans-unit.source: No actual input directory exists, but due to the presence of the slash character in the key name, it has the appearance of a file path.
trans-unit.target: No actual input directory exists, but due to the presence of the slash character in the key name, it has the appearance of a file path.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Benefits of Blob storage
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Benefits of Blob storage

trans-unit.source: The implied performance cost of not co-locating compute clusters and storage resources is mitigated by the way the compute clusters are provisioned close to the storage account resources inside the Azure datacenter, where the high-speed network makes it very efficient for the compute nodes to access the data inside Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: The implied performance cost of not co-locating compute clusters and storage resources is mitigated by the way the compute clusters are provisioned close to the storage account resources inside the Azure datacenter, where the high-speed network makes it very efficient for the compute nodes to access the data inside Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: There are several benefits associated with storing the data in Azure Blob storage instead of HDFS:
trans-unit.target: There are several benefits associated with storing the data in Azure Blob storage instead of HDFS:

trans-unit.source: Data reuse and sharing: The data in HDFS is located inside the compute cluster.
trans-unit.target: Data reuse and sharing: The data in HDFS is located inside the compute cluster.

trans-unit.source: Only the applications that have access to the compute cluster can use the data by using HDFS APIs.
trans-unit.target: Only the applications that have access to the compute cluster can use the data by using HDFS APIs.

trans-unit.source: The data in Azure Blob storage can be accessed either through the HDFS APIs or through the <link><linkText>Blob Storage REST APIs[blob-storage-restapi]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The data in Azure Blob storage can be accessed either through the HDFS APIs or through the <link><linkText>Blob Storage REST APIs[blob-storage-restapi]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Thus, a larger set of applications (including other HDInsight clusters) and tools can be used to produce and consume the data.
trans-unit.target: Thus, a larger set of applications (including other HDInsight clusters) and tools can be used to produce and consume the data.

trans-unit.source: Data archiving: Storing data in Azure Blob storage enables the HDInsight clusters used for computation to be safely deleted without losing user data.
trans-unit.target: Data archiving: Storing data in Azure Blob storage enables the HDInsight clusters used for computation to be safely deleted without losing user data.

trans-unit.source: Data storage cost: Storing data in DFS for the long term is more costly than storing the data in Azure Blob storage because the cost of a compute cluster is higher than the cost of an Azure Blob storage container.
trans-unit.target: Data storage cost: Storing data in DFS for the long term is more costly than storing the data in Azure Blob storage because the cost of a compute cluster is higher than the cost of an Azure Blob storage container.

trans-unit.source: In addition, because the data does not have to be reloaded for every compute cluster generation, you are also saving data loading costs.
trans-unit.target: In addition, because the data does not have to be reloaded for every compute cluster generation, you are also saving data loading costs.

trans-unit.source: Elastic scale-out: Although HDFS provides you with a scaled-out file system, the scale is determined by the number of nodes that you provision for your cluster.
trans-unit.target: Elastic scale-out: Although HDFS provides you with a scaled-out file system, the scale is determined by the number of nodes that you provision for your cluster.

trans-unit.source: Changing the scale can become a more complicated process than relying on the elastic scaling capabilities that you get automatically in Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: Changing the scale can become a more complicated process than relying on the elastic scaling capabilities that you get automatically in Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: Geo-replication: Your Azure Blob storage containers can be geo-replicated.
trans-unit.target: Geo-replication: Your Azure Blob storage containers can be geo-replicated.

trans-unit.source: Although this gives you geographic recovery and data redundancy, a failover to the geo-replicated location severely impacts your performance, and it may incur additional costs.
trans-unit.target: Although this gives you geographic recovery and data redundancy, a failover to the geo-replicated location severely impacts your performance, and it may incur additional costs.

trans-unit.source: So our recommendation is to choose the geo-replication wisely and only if the value of the data is worth the additional cost.
trans-unit.target: So our recommendation is to choose the geo-replication wisely and only if the value of the data is worth the additional cost.

trans-unit.source: Certain MapReduce jobs and packages may create intermediate results that you don't really want to store in Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: Certain MapReduce jobs and packages may create intermediate results that you don't really want to store in Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: In that case, you can elect to store the data in the local HDFS.
trans-unit.target: In that case, you can elect to store the data in the local HDFS.

trans-unit.source: In fact, HDInsight uses DFS for several of these intermediate results in Hive jobs and other processes.
trans-unit.target: In fact, HDInsight uses DFS for several of these intermediate results in Hive jobs and other processes.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Create a blob container
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Create a blob container

trans-unit.source: To use blobs, you first create an <link><linkText>Azure Storage account[azure-storage-create]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To use blobs, you first create an <link><linkText>Azure Storage account[azure-storage-create]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: As part of this, you specify an Azure datacenter that will store the objects you create using this account.
trans-unit.target: As part of this, you specify an Azure datacenter that will store the objects you create using this account.

trans-unit.source: The cluster and the storage account must be hosted in the same datacenter.
trans-unit.target: The cluster and the storage account must be hosted in the same datacenter.

trans-unit.source: The Hive metastore SQL Server database and Oozie metastore SQL Server database must also be located in the same datacenter.
trans-unit.target: The Hive metastore SQL Server database and Oozie metastore SQL Server database must also be located in the same datacenter.

trans-unit.source: Wherever it lives, each blob you create belongs to a container in your Azure Storage account.
trans-unit.target: Wherever it lives, each blob you create belongs to a container in your Azure Storage account.

trans-unit.source: This container may be an existing blob that was created outside of HDInsight, or it may be a container that is created for an HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: This container may be an existing blob that was created outside of HDInsight, or it may be a container that is created for an HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Don't share a default storage container with multiple HDInsight clusters.
trans-unit.target: Don't share a default storage container with multiple HDInsight clusters.

trans-unit.source: If you need to use a shared container to provide access to data for multiple HDInsight clusters then you should add it as an additional storage account in the cluster configuration.
trans-unit.target: If you need to use a shared container to provide access to data for multiple HDInsight clusters then you should add it as an additional storage account in the cluster configuration.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Provision HDInsight clusters[hdinsight-provision]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Provision HDInsight clusters[hdinsight-provision]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: However you can reuse a default storage container after the original HDInsight cluster has been deleted.
trans-unit.target: However you can reuse a default storage container after the original HDInsight cluster has been deleted.

trans-unit.source: For HBase clusters, you can actually retain the HBase table schema and data by provision a new HBase cluster using the default blob storage container that is used by an HBase cluster that has been deleted.
trans-unit.target: For HBase clusters, you can actually retain the HBase table schema and data by provision a new HBase cluster using the default blob storage container that is used by an HBase cluster that has been deleted.

trans-unit.source: Using the Azure preview portal
trans-unit.target: Using the Azure preview portal

trans-unit.source: When provisioning an HDInsight cluster from the preview portal, you have the options to use an existing storage account or create a new storage account:
trans-unit.target: When provisioning an HDInsight cluster from the preview portal, you have the options to use an existing storage account or create a new storage account:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>hdinsight hadoop provision data source</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>hdinsight hadoop provision data source</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Using Azure CLI
trans-unit.target: Using Azure CLI

trans-unit.source: If you have <link><linkText>installed and configured the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title></link>, the following command can be used to a storage account and container.
trans-unit.target: If you have <link><linkText>installed and configured the Azure CLI</linkText><title></title></link>, the following command can be used to a storage account and container.

trans-unit.source: The --type parameter indicates how the storage account will be replicated.
trans-unit.target: The --type parameter indicates how the storage account will be replicated.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Azure Storage Replication</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Azure Storage Replication</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to specify the geographic region that the storage account will be located in.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to specify the geographic region that the storage account will be located in.

trans-unit.source: You should create the storage account in the same region that you plan on creating your HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: You should create the storage account in the same region that you plan on creating your HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Once the storage account is created, use the following command to retrieve the storage account keys:
trans-unit.target: Once the storage account is created, use the following command to retrieve the storage account keys:

trans-unit.target: If you <link><linkText>installed and configured Azure PowerShell[powershell-install]</linkText><title></title></link>, you can use the following from the Azure PowerShell prompt to create a storage account and container:

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Address files in Blob storage
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Address files in Blob storage

trans-unit.source: The URI scheme for accessing files in Blob storage from HDInsight is:
trans-unit.target: The URI scheme for accessing files in Blob storage from HDInsight is:

trans-unit.source: The syntax for addressing the files on the storage emulator (running on HDInsight emulator) is <html></html>wasb://<ContainerName>@storageemulator<html></html>.
trans-unit.target: The syntax for addressing the files on the storage emulator (running on HDInsight emulator) is <html></html>wasb://<ContainerName>@storageemulator<html></html>.

trans-unit.source: The URI scheme provides unencrypted access (with the wasb: prefix) and SSL encrypted access (with wasbs).
trans-unit.target: The URI scheme provides unencrypted access (with the wasb: prefix) and SSL encrypted access (with wasbs).

trans-unit.source: We recommend using wasbs wherever possible, even when accessing data that lives inside the same datacenter in Azure.
trans-unit.target: We recommend using wasbs wherever possible, even when accessing data that lives inside the same datacenter in Azure.

trans-unit.source: The <BlobStorageContainerName> identifies the name of the container in Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: The <BlobStorageContainerName> identifies the name of the container in Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: The <StorageAccountName> identifies the Azure Storage account name.
trans-unit.target: The <StorageAccountName> identifies the Azure Storage account name.

trans-unit.source: A fully qualified domain name (FQDN) is required.
trans-unit.target: A fully qualified domain name (FQDN) is required.

trans-unit.source: If neither <BlobStorageContainerName> nor <StorageAccountName> has been specified, the default file system is used.
trans-unit.target: If neither <BlobStorageContainerName> nor <StorageAccountName> has been specified, the default file system is used.

trans-unit.source: For the files on the default file system, you can use a relative path or an absolute path.
trans-unit.target: For the files on the default file system, you can use a relative path or an absolute path.

trans-unit.source: For example, the hadoop-mapreduce-examples.jar file that comes with HDInsight clusters can be referred to by using one of the following:
trans-unit.target: For example, the hadoop-mapreduce-examples.jar file that comes with HDInsight clusters can be referred to by using one of the following:

trans-unit.source: The file name is <html></html>hadoop-examples.jar<html></html> in HDInsight versions 2.1 and 1.6 clusters.
trans-unit.target: The file name is <html></html>hadoop-examples.jar<html></html> in HDInsight versions 2.1 and 1.6 clusters.

trans-unit.source: The <path> is the file or directory HDFS path name.
trans-unit.target: The <path> is the file or directory HDFS path name.

trans-unit.source: Because containers in Azure Blob storage are simply key-value stores, there is no true hierarchical file system.
trans-unit.target: Because containers in Azure Blob storage are simply key-value stores, there is no true hierarchical file system.

trans-unit.source: A slash character ( / ) inside a blob key is interpreted as a directory separator.
trans-unit.target: A slash character ( / ) inside a blob key is interpreted as a directory separator.

trans-unit.source: For example, the blob name for hadoop-mapreduce-examples.jar is:
trans-unit.target: For example, the blob name for hadoop-mapreduce-examples.jar is:

trans-unit.source: When working with blobs outside of HDInsight, most utilities do not recognize the WASB format and instead expect a basic path format, such as example/jars/hadoop-mapreduce-examples.jar.
trans-unit.target: When working with blobs outside of HDInsight, most utilities do not recognize the WASB format and instead expect a basic path format, such as example/jars/hadoop-mapreduce-examples.jar.

trans-unit.target: (The next example shows how to use the Invoke-Hive cmdlet to execute the dfs ls command to list a folder.)

trans-unit.source: Example of using Azure PowerShell to run a Hive query using an undefined storage account
trans-unit.target: Example of using Azure PowerShell to run a Hive query using an undefined storage account

trans-unit.source: This example shows how to list a folder from storage account that is not defined during the provisioning process.
trans-unit.target: This example shows how to list a folder from storage account that is not defined during the provisioning process.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Next steps
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Next steps

trans-unit.source: In this article, you learned how to use HDFS-compatible Azure Blob storage with HDInsight, and you learned that Azure Blob storage is a fundamental component of HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: In this article, you learned how to use HDFS-compatible Azure Blob storage with HDInsight, and you learned that Azure Blob storage is a fundamental component of HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: This allows you to build scalable, long-term, archiving data acquisition solutions with Azure Blob storage and use HDInsight to unlock the information inside the stored structured and unstructured data.
trans-unit.target: This allows you to build scalable, long-term, archiving data acquisition solutions with Azure Blob storage and use HDInsight to unlock the information inside the stored structured and unstructured data.
